title: Sheet 3E
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">This charcoal and black chalk image of Christ borrows from Albert Bouts’s painting The Man of Sorrows (fig. 1) and exhibits Ensor’s earlier drawing style. At some point the crown of thorns was rubbed away; the shako (the military hat worn by the Belgian civil guard) is a later addition, added in a slightly darker black colored pencil or crayon (possibly Conté; see fig. 2; see “Ensor’s Panache” for more on the shako and other military headgear of Ensor’s time). Although difficult to read under normal conditions, the crown of thorns is identifiable with the aid of infrared reflectography (see fig. 3). Additional strokes emphasize the beard and some outer strands of hair. A monstrance, or ostensorium (used to display the consecrated host), extends to either side of Christ’s face (sheets 3D and 3F). SMC/KJN

fig. 1 Albert Bouts (Netherlandish, c. 1452–1549). The Man of Sorrows, 1490/1500. Oil on panel; 29 × 29 cm (11 7/16 × 11 7/16 in.). Royal Museum of Fine Arts, Antwerp, 250. © Lukas—Art in Flanders VZW, photograph by Hugo Maertens.

fig. 2 Detail from folio 2D/E and sheet 3E of Ensor’s Temptation of Saint Anthony (1887–88) showing Christ’s head. The blue dotted lines near the face indicate an earlier drawing of a crown of thorns, while the yellow lines trace the feathered shako that was added later. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2006.87.

fig. 3 Infrared image of sheet 3E of Ensor’s Temptation of Saint Anthony (1887–88). The Art Institute of Chicago, 2006.87.
